The question is too cute by considerably more then half. If you hadn’t specifically asked me, I wouldn’t be addressing this. First it’s not grounded in anything wise, defined or really much of anything else. How then can the answers be meaningful when they have to grapple with the smoke that is the question? “Unethical” has a wide range of meaning, ethics having to do with the philosophy of morality mostly. I can only assume you’re using it in a colloquial way to mean immoral. Can good come out of bad? - is what you’re trying to explore, your premise being that if many benefit, that has to make it at least more OK. Its the quintessential slippery slope argument at its worst. I’m often but not necessarily, not a fan of this argument but particularly here. If you start out with something that you know is fundamentally wrong & then try to ameliorate it, then it necessarily corrupts all that follows. The rule of thumb is, the reverse is always but always better to strive for. Starting with something good & then minimizing the worst or “unethical” aspects. In real time especially. The first is simply cynicism, which is the one thing there must always be zero tolerance for. Skepticism is of course necessary but this is not that. The human imagination is the preeminent characteristic that makes humans more powerful (for good or ill) then any other life form. It allows one to rationalize the premise of this question. You’re a CEO of a business in LA Peter, & this question strongly smacks of the pragmatic. The word & concept is mostly used to insist that the lowest hanging fruit must always be reached for & reaching any higher is very aggressively dismissed. This dovetails rather neatly with the core principle & engine that drives all capitalism: Removing any & all obstacles to generating capital. Please understand, I’m an entrepreneur so I well understand the priority of creatively inserting morality into business in such a way that trust is established makes life worthwhile on so many levels. Also, my becoming a part of all the ugliness of the world is at least very usefully minimized. Instead of “pragmatic” I use the word practical. Lets get to the heart of the matter this all revolves around. Morality can be usefully defined in clear even stark terms that are scientifically irrefutable. A first principle of demonstrable, axiomatic truth. For starters, it is indisputably not a psychological or social construct. It is incontrovertibly biological at the very deepest levels. Morality is an outgrowth of our biological capacity for empathy. Out of which Love (& all healthy socialization) also emerges that we exercise, because we are also intrinsically social creatures. Everything important in the most practical terms, attempting to express itself in sublime ways is mostly composed of Love - Integrity, dedication, authentic sincerity, honesty (especially with oneself), courage, honour etc. & must be a component of everything done or its literally worthless.* This is because empathy is a biological instinct so much bigger than any one of us. It's there for the perpetuation of the species. We would neither procreate w/o it or nearly as often or have any meaningful intimacy with virtually anyone - or stick around to raise the offspring. This is why emotional intelligence & empathy are just a form of this & the inevitable reason why it is the best predictor of all levels of the most profound happiness, fulfillment, success & prosperity in life. The unconscious will always rebel if this is suppressed & denied otherwise. In terms of a compromised immune system - within minutes (countless studies have shown). Opening us up to every 1) Physical & 2) Psychological malady - as unconscious anxieties ever intrude on our conscious life, requiring increasing effort to contain & making us psychologically unbalanced as our anxieties increasingly intrude on oour conscious mind (the textbook definition of insanity - it being a matter of degree). Honouring it is thus necessarily where all lasting joy (not just a component of it, pleasure) & all levels & kinds of prosperity lies. I understand how this can all get blurred in business & when one is dealing with Artists & the Los Angeles community. I say this next not unsympathetically. I once saw a repeat of a special 2 part episode of the original Law & Order series (done well before the CSI derivatives) where one of the detectives has gone to LA to chase a criminal & at the end of the second episode is chatting with a female V.P. of a Hollywood studio. She tells him she’s leaving the business. He exclaims, “You’re so good at it, why would you want to leave!” Her reply I’ve been told by many who’ve done business in LA is uncomfortably close to describing a sensibility that is unfortunately too common. She replied, “I’m tired of being in an industry where everyone talks like hippies - but acts like hit men.” The selfishly pragmatic propelled by fear based reasoning, self indulgence & psychological laziness, is apparently somewhat greater there, then many other business cultures in N.A. It can be a challenge to navigate through I’m sure, especially when there are so many enablers implicit within it. The creativity used to passionately rationalize the “unethical” there are legendary. *The shortcut that will always tell you most directly if something is intrinsically moral to a meaningful degree, is look for any of the components that are mostly made up of Love mentioned. If the cleverness & fear (& all the selfishness & psychological laziness that are emanate from it) dominate, you have your answer. It’s not always perfectly simple to do but its always the place you start that yields the the best results most frequently & consistently. Even trying & looking like you are builds trust & respect from everyone.

The whole point of declaring something unethical—when the term is used right—is to say something shouldn’t be done because it’s not worth an intangible cost. So, the unethical experiment that would have the biggest positive impact is likely one that’s just almost worth doing. The experiments most often called ‘unethical’ inappropriately are mostly those that involve stem cell research. Religious people in the United States have some very strange beliefs surrounding human conception, involving ‘souls’ and applying human rights to things that aren’t human in any meaningful way, and this has been blocking vital, life-saving medical research that could benefit all of humanity. I don’t know which specific experiments could be most helpful. It’s hard to know until after they’ve been completed, more than once. But the field in general has a lot of untapped potential. There’s many people that will never be able to have children of their own unless more research is done in this area, and stem cell research is relevant to curing cancer and congenital illnesses, and creating replacement organs without the need for an organ donor. It doesn’t hurt anyone, since human embryos are not people—it would make more sense to ban the use of lab rats than to ban the use of so-called ‘babies’ that have developed for less than seven weeks since conception. Abortions occur naturally at this stage of development all the time, without potential mothers even being aware of it. Unfortunately, the public is not well educated about this, and often intentionally misled by their religious and political leaders.

I think if we could find some way to round up all hypothetical questioners who craft scenarios that attempt to prove situation ethics or moral relativism useful, and strap the situation ethics people to one trolley track, and strap the moral relativism people to another, and then take, say, one logical positivist, and strap him or her to the switch, and instruct the logical positivist as follows: “These are parallel, non-intersecting tracks. One has a trolley coming down it. The other has a trolley coming up it. The switch you are tied to connects to nothing. WHAT DO YOU DO?” Then while the logical positivist is sputtering protests, CLACKALACKA WOOOSH! Both trolleys roll by! CRUNCH! Arms flying one way! CRUNCH! Legs flying another! The whole thing could be televised. I bet it would sour a lot of people on the value of bullshit. They’d be like, “Hey, that was a no-win proposition purely designed to cloud our sweet clean decent moral clarity and get us to hesitate for real in a true life situation with everything riding on it!” And to anyone not thereby discouraged, it would provide at least a stern warning. Oh, by the way: no unethical experiment can benefit society. For whatever else its effect may be, it encourages the already pernicious and dangerous impression among professional experimenters that they should circumvent ethics without regard for their protection of and benefit to society, if a neat experiment has been thought of that can’t be done (at this time) within them. Also: humanity is water running downhill. The silt of our ignorance washes away, to expose the hard substrate of reality’s limits and attributes. The knowable is inevitable. We needn’t run dangerous shortcuts through the few recognized ethical checks and blocks we’ve actually managed to agree upon. Ignoring safety and ethical requirements (such as for informed consent) will jeopardize more lives across the board than any mad dash you think will get us there faster in one case can possible save. The performers of the experiment should also be killed. I’ve decided. While we’re at it. That would have some value (deterrent), and tend to work a corrective on the otherwise bad impression created. While I’m at it, the experiment should cure cancer! I’m not sure how one can cure cancer by running over a lot of people with trolleys, but as long as we’re dreaming and wishing away, hey why not! And isn’t it worth the sacrifice, to cure cancer in a one-time gross violation of ethics and be summarily executed for your trouble? I say it is. It is to me. And I’m the one who designed the brilliant, cancer-cure death trolley experiment, so! Come get me. Soon as the headlines cry “CANCER CURED! RANDOM HYPOTHETICAL-SLAUGHTERING TROLLEY MASTERMIND JACKASS ON QUORA RESPONSIBLE! DEATH BE UNTO HIM FOR DOING IT UNETHICALLY,” I’ll be satisfied. I’d be a martyr to something people won’t even be able to explain. Probably cop a sweet Nobel Prize! My legacy would be something unspeakable. These are all just hypothetical people, mind you. To be clear; to reassure all. Everyone in my answer is as hypothetical as the question was. If you could cure real cancer by executing hypothetical people, wouldn’t you? Even if I had to die in the process? Pay no attention to the trolley. Keep off the track, though. Just in case.
